content: The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008, also known as the Traumatic Brain Injury Act, includes amendments to the Public Health Service Act related to restructuring and renaming sections concerning prevention and registries of traumatic brain injuries. Additionally, the Act addresses Traumatic Brain Injury Programs of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008 amends the Public Health Service Act to update the prevention and surveillance of traumatic brain injuries. It includes changes to the national program for traumatic brain injury surveillance and registries, focusing on data collection and state-operated surveillance systems. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008 updates the State's surveillance system for traumatic brain injuries to collect data, ensure reporting uniformity, link individuals to services, and support research. The Secretary must report on these changes within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008 requires a report to be submitted to Congress on improving the collection and dissemination of epidemiological studies on traumatic brain injury in military veterans, along with recommendations for collaboration on diagnostic tools and treatments. SEC. 4. STUDY ON TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY. A new section is added to the Public Health Service Act for a study on traumatic brain injury. The Secretary may conduct a study on traumatic brain injury to determine its incidence, prevalence, and clinical aspects in the US population, including different age and ethnic groups. This study includes reporting national trends in traumatic brain injury, identifying common therapeutic interventions used for rehabilitation, analyzing their effectiveness in improving functioning, and comparing their effectiveness in rehabilitation. The study aims to identify interventions and therapies that can prevent or remediate the development of secondary neurologic conditions related to traumatic brain injury and develop practice guidelines for the rehabilitation of traumatic brain injury when appropriate scientific research becomes available. The Secretary is required to submit a report not later than 3 years after the enactment of the Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008. The Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008 requires the Secretary to submit a report to Congress on findings related to traumatic brain injuries. The definition of traumatic brain injury excludes brain dysfunction from congenital or degenerative disorders but includes injuries caused by trauma like near drowning. The Secretary has the authority to revise the definition as needed. SEC. 5 amends Section 1261 of the Public Health Service Act to update the Traumatic Brain Injury Programs of the National Institutes of Health. SEC. 6 addresses Traumatic Brain Injury Programs of the Health Resources and Services Administration. Section 1252 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include American Indian consortia in state grants for demonstration projects regarding traumatic brain injury. The amendment also updates recommendations to include American Indian consortia. The amendment to Section 1252 of the Public Health Service Act includes American Indian consortia in state grants for traumatic brain injury projects and updates recommendations to involve them. The amendment expands state grants for traumatic brain injury projects to include American Indian consortia and updates recommendations for involvement. The amendment expands state grants for traumatic brain injury projects to include American Indian consortia and updates definitions related to brain injuries. The amendment revises definitions related to brain injuries, expands state grants for traumatic brain injury projects to include American Indian consortia, and updates funding allocations for fiscal years 2009 through 2012. The amendment includes provisions for data collection and training grants related to protection and advocacy services for individuals with disabilities. The amendment defines an eligible national association as one with experience in training and assisting protection and advocacy systems. Protection and advocacy systems are granted the same authorities for accessing records as under the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000. Subsection (l) is amended to cover the years 2009 through 2012.
